captions.text:
You may remember the last time we here at
Zero Punctuation shoved our critical periscope

right up Conan the Barbarian&#39;s loincloth,
it was for Age of Conan, quite a few years

ago now, one of Funcom&#39;s many attempts at
Mumorpugers that went the way of all the others

&#39;cos running a Mumorpuger is like having to
share your house with an incontinent giraffe

that&#39;s constantly injuring itself on the staircase
and incessantly complaining to you about how
the PVP&#39;s unbalanced.

But massive online role playing was a natural
fit for the Conan universe, because where

else could the gameplay capture the feeling
of being strapped to a grinding wheel for
twenty fucking years?
Ell, oh, and furthermore, ell.

Age of Conan was a perfectly faithful adaptation
in that there were a lot of deserts in it

and player characters had the option of running
around with their giggle zones hanging out

like they were role playing as a Boris Vallejo
painting.

This was a privilege you may recall I immediately
set out to abuse by creating the character

of Thinderella the Necromantic Naturist and
vowing never to constrain my giggle zones
with earthly fabrics.

Imagine my joy, then, to discover that Conan
Exiles is bringing the wonder of the giggle

zone to a new generation and the opportunity
arose for Thinderella to ride again.

Although after turning all the body sliders
down to minimum, Thinderella was still rocking

a monster booty, which was slightly disappointing,
but then I suppose this is the nature of body

types in the Conan universe; if your thigh
muscles are only as big as medium-sized pool

floats you officially qualify for humanitarian
aid.

So, with Conan Sexiles Funcom are having another
spin of the severely unbalanced roulette table

that is Mumorpuger development, so let&#39;s hope
- excuse me, Yahtzee Croshaw of the internet,

but Conan Exiles isn&#39;t a mumorpuger, it&#39;s
a survival game.
Oh forgive me.

I got confused because it&#39;s a role-playing
game that&#39;s massively multiplayer and online.

Oh yes, and the gameplay is largely concerned
with grinding up specific numbers of items
all bloody day.
&quot;Yes, granted, smartarse.

But the difference is, you have to come up
with the grindy fetch quests yourself.
It&#39;s like self-flagellation, but with boredom.
Oh yes, and you can play it single player.&quot;

Well, that sounds to me like the perfect excuse
to see if it holds up as a single player game.

You know what I&#39;m like with other people,
I&#39;m fine with them on principle, manufacturing

things and driving buses and shit, I just
can&#39;t stand when they try to relate to you

or ask you to stop making lampshades out of
their flesh.

Besides, there&#39;s a chance if I join a multiplayer
server that they might have turned nudity

off, and that would have been completely offensive
to Thinderella&#39;s lifestyle choices.

So the game starts promisingly with your character
already in their skivvies and nailed to a

cross in the middle of a desert, although
the process has done fuck all to make you

less beach body ready, so Conan the Barbarian
in his obligatory contractual appearance shows

up, cuts you down, and leaves you to figure
out the rest yourself.

Fortunately there&#39;s a source of fresh water
about five minutes&#39; walk away since the authorities

were probably busy and couldn&#39;t be bothered
looking for a really BIG desert to abandon
you in.

So Thinderella started heading over there,
picking up enough plant fibres on the way

to craft a complete set of clothing for herself,
by which I mean, one pair of hand wraps and
some flip-flops.
Although it wasn&#39;t quite as intuitive as that.

Surprisingly for a modern game there aren&#39;t
any contextual button prompts, you just have

to figure out that you&#39;re supposed to stand
in front of a bush and keep mashing X until

all the useful parts of the bush are extracted,
meaning the bits that were stopping the rest

of the bush from disintegrating and mysteriously
fading from existence.

Also, you drink water by standing in some
water and mashing X until you have sucked

enough moisture in through your kneecaps,
and here&#39;s my advanced level tip: if your

giggle zone starts to bloodily disappear,
that&#39;s an alligator.
You should probably move.

But it did make me realise that naturism has
really caught on in the Conan universe since

our last visit, as every time you die the
game strips you naked again and deposits you
on the spawn point with no stuff.

Par for the course, really, but after you
streak into the cave of enemies you died in

last time and desperately mash the &quot;take all&quot;
button over your corpse as several nonplused

giant spiders gather to nibble your bum, the
game also doesn&#39;t re-equip everything, so

you have to then streak back out, climb a
tree and patiently glue all your tools and

weapons back to your quick select wheel before
you can fight back.

And some of these monsters really don&#39;t know
how to take a fucking hint.

I ran across two entire fucking biomes once
and the giant spiders were still nipping at
me flip flops.
Damn this extremely attractive bottom of mine.

But I found a nice quiet spot to set up base
camp that was convenient for the river, the

local spider cave and the rock, tree and bush
emporium and started progressing my way up
the tech tree.

Make a stone pickaxe, one bit of wood, five
rocks, gotcha.

Make a bedroll, one bit of wood, five leaves,
that&#39;s done, now make a wooden storage box,

one hundred bits of wood - whoa whoa whoa,
that was a fucking jump.

I only wanted a footlocker, not a fucking
Regency wardrobe with complimentary portal
to Narnia.
Now let&#39;s build a tannery.
That&#39;ll be 240 rocks - what?

It&#39;s, like three bits of wood with skin stretched
over it.

What&#39;re the rocks for, you gonna put it on
a gravel driveway?

Look, we&#39;re just making sure you get the full
intended experience, that is to say, wasting

hours of your life banging a rock with another,
smaller, pointier bit of rock.

My progress up the tech tree then hit a bit
of a beehive when I suddenly needed 100 bits
of iron to make a blacksmith&#39;s bench.
And I hadn&#39;t seen any iron up to then.

Well, tell a lie, I found one ingot in a dead
bandit&#39;s loincloth, which I can only assume

he was hoping would impress all the naked
women on corpse runs, but I resolved to look

this up before I set up a bandit concentration
camp, mindful as I am of the perverse glee

with which survival games refuse to tell you
shit.

One trip to the wiki later, it turned out
that there were some iron deposits that spawned

in select locations around the mountains half
an hour&#39;s trudge away like nature&#39;s pubic

thatches and I&#39;d just have to mine them all,
let them respawn, then repeat.

Blimey, lucky this wasn&#39;t multiplayer, you
probably have to sign up for a waiting list.

But now that I had iron, I could finally explore
the game&#39;s most enticing feature, building

a fuck-off torture wheel to turn NPCs into
my slaves.

Weirdly, the wheel came with a dude already
on it despite being ostensibly empty, maybe
he was the model they use for shop floor demonstrations.

I clouted a bandit from the nearby camp around
the skull, dragged him over - incidentally

this is where we discover that you can&#39;t drag
and climb so hope you didn&#39;t build your base

somewhere you can only access by climbing
like some kind of sensible person who understands

base defense - and shoved them up the demonstration
model dude&#39;s butt.

Thirty boring minutes on gas mark four later,
my brand new slave popped out and Thinderella
promptly stored him away on her person.
Somehow.
Let&#39;s not speculate.

I equipped him, planted him on the floor and
he proceeded to fucking stand there.

&quot;Would you like to come and mine some iron
with me, slave?&quot;

&quot;No, I&#39;m a fighter, I&#39;ll just stay here and
guard your base from fuck all.

My sword&#39;s kinda shitty, though, better grind
me up a nicer one.&quot;

And that was when I decided I&#39;d had enough
of Colon Textiles.

When I end every play session by declaring
&quot;Bollocks to this shit,&quot; that&#39;s probably all
you need for review purposes.

It&#39;s hard to come back from a bollocks to
this shit situation.

And your bollocks won&#39;t appreciate it much
either.
